title: Amroth to Saundersfoot Walk Route

images.title: Humphrey Bolton [CC BY-SA 2.0 (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0)], via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Cliffs, Amroth

images.title: Trevor Rickard [CC BY-SA 2.0 (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0)], via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Sea Front at Wiseman's Bridge. The beach was the stage for rehearsals of the D-Day landings during the Second World War.

images.title: Pauline Eccles [CC BY-SA 2.0 (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0)], via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Coastal path enters the tunnel

images.title: Don Cawthra [CC BY-SA 2.0 (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0)], via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Tree on Saundersfoot beach

images.title: Stuart Logan / Amroth Castle
images.caption: Amroth Castle. A Grade I listed building on the walk. It is a castellated country house dating mainly from the 18th century built on an earlier, probably 15th century, residence, and is now a holiday venue.

images.title: Amroth beach by BARRIE TRIGG, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Amroth beach

images.title: Garth Newton / Coppet Hall Point
images.caption: Coppet Hall Point. The unusual rock formation on the beach is due to a prehistoric lava flow. Wiseman's Bridge can be seen in the distance with Amroth further to the right.

images.title: Mike Graham / Coppit Hall beach
images.caption: Coppit Hall beach. Stream running down the beach over tropical looking beach in Wales!

description: A short walk along a delightful stretch of the Pembrokeshire Coast. The route takes you between the lovely villages of Amroth and Saundersfoot, with pretty beaches, cliff tops and coastal views. The walk is about 2.5 miles with a moderate climb at the start before a nice flat path leads you into Saundersfoot. Along the way you'll pass the long sandy beach in Amroth and the rocky beach at Wiseman's Bridge. In Saundersfoot the walk finishes, passing another nice beach and the lovely harbour. To extend your walking in Amroth you can visit Amroth and Colby Woodland Garden, just to the north of the village. The National Trust owned property has some good woodland trails to try. You could also continue on the Pembrokeshire Coast Path to nearby Tenby. On the google street view link below you can virtually explore the coast path!

details.subtitle: Pubs/Cafes
details.content: The Wiseman's Bridge Inn is in a great location on the beach in the little hamlet. They serve good quality dishes and also provide rooms if you wish to stay in the area.

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: If you head east along the Wales coast path you can visit the wonderful Pendine Sands on the Pendine to Amroth Coastal Path. The wide beach is the location of many world land speed record attempts by people such as Sir Malcolm Campbell in Bluebird.
